articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website
articles.contents:
About Me
I’m Farhan
Sadeek from Columbus, Ohio, currently studying as a rising
Sophomore at Dublin Coffman High School, OH with an interest in
Electrical Engineering, Nuclear Physics and Data Science. I like to read
non-fiction, and spend time with my family members.
About the Project
Analysis of World Population and Economy
3rd planet from the Sun, Earth is home to 193 nations. Economically
all the nations are different from each other. All these nations differ
from one another in different ways. The purpose of this project is to
identify those differences and investigate the root cause with the help
of data science.
Goals
Identify different indices of life index
Investigate how economy impacts those indices
“This is Data Science”

Preceptor

articles.title: Analysis of World Population and Economy
articles.description: This website would give you an idea about the current world population and different indices based upon population.
articles.contents:
Density
The relation between population of a country is depicted in the graph
below. Key finding from this graph is “Except micronations there
is no correlation between population and density”



The key takeaways from this graph:
The population density can be as low as 20 and
go all the way to 10000 per square kilometer.
Most countries regardless of their location, income or economic
progress tend to have the similar population density.
Growth Rate
The relation between growth rate of a country and per capita income
is depicted in the graph below. Key finding from this graph is “Growth
rate is inversely proportional to per capita income.”









The key takeaways from this graph:
Most countries tend to have density around 100 to 500 per square
kilometer.
Countries with low income fall into the
developing category and have very high growth
rate.
Countries with high income fall into the
developed category and have very low growth
rate. Generally those countries have a growth rate lying
between -1% and 1%.
Economic Progress



Key takeaways from the graph are listed below:
Europe is dominated by developed countries, but
the rest are filled with developing countries.
Developing countries are more common that developed
countries.
South America, North America
and Africa is filled with mostly developing
countries.
Asia and Oceania is consists of
both developing and developed countries.
Lending Category and Economy
IDA stands for International Development
Association, which is one of the largest and most effective
platforms for fighting extreme poverty in the world’s poorest countries.
On the other hand, IBRD stands for the
International Bank for Reconstruction and Development,
commonly referred as World Bank. IBRD
assists the development of its member nation’s territories, promotes and
supplements private foreign investment and promoting long-range
balance.






Key takeaways from the graph are listed below:
Most developing countries are located in
Africa. So these nations have to depend a lot on loans
from IDA to develop the quality of life.
Europe is the most developed continent, therefore, most European
nations don’t need any loans to operate their economy.
Asia consists of both developed and developing nations. So
there’s a diversity among Asian nations.

articles.title: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs
articles.description: This project consists of multiple datasets. From the United Nations site the Population dataset was collected.

author.name: United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs

articles.contents:
The 2019 Revision of World Population Prospects is the twenty-sixth
round of official United Nations population estimates and projections
that have been prepared by the Population Division of the Department of
Economic and Social Affairs of the United Nations Secretariat.
Learn more about using Distill for R Markdown at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

articles.title: World Bank Open Data
articles.description: World bank site contains the economic progress dataset used in the porject
articles.contents:
Data displayed on world bank open dataset site are a subset of those
available in the World Bank’s DataBank, which contains extensive
collections of time series data. The DataBank has advanced functions for
selecting and slicing the datasets, performing customized queries and
data downloads, and creating charts and other visualizations.

articles.title: Kaggle
articles.description: An overview of sources used in my project.
articles.contents:
Although there have been lot of studies undertaken in the past on
factors affecting life expectancy considering demographic variables,
income composition and mortality rates. It was found that affect of
immunization and human development index was not taken into account in
the past. Also, some of the past research was done considering multiple
linear regression based on data set of one year for all the countries.
Hence, this gives motivation to resolve both the factors stated
previously by formulating a regression model based on mixed effects
model and multiple linear regression while considering data from a
period of 2000 to 2015 for all the countries. Important immunization
like Hepatitis B, Polio and Diphtheria will also be considered. In a
nutshell, this study will focus on immunization factors, mortality
factors, economic factors, social factors and other health related
factors as well. Since the observations this dataset are based on
different countries, it will be easier for a country to determine the
predicting factor which is contributing to lower value of life
expectancy. This will help in suggesting a country which area should be
given importance in order to efficiently improve the life expectancy of
its population.
